items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely to continue today, Thursday 9 December, overnight and into tomorrow. Water levels are starting to drop, however further rainfall is expected overnight and into tomorrow which is likely to cause levels to rise again. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Friday 10 December.
This flood alert is no longer in force due to levels falling below levels of concern. We will continue to monitor the situation and forecast and re-issue if necessary.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Following recent rainfall, river levels on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water remain high. Flooding is forecast to affect low  lying areas near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water.  With little rain forecast, levels are expected to peak later this afternoon before starting to recede. Avoid using low lying footpaths, particularly around the lake edge and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Thursday 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen overnight at the Basford Bridge river gauge as a result of rainfall associated with Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle. Further rainfall is forecast later this afternoon (Thursday 9 December 2021). We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated later this evening, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Marchington Brook, Picknall Brook, Rolleston Brook

items.message: River levels have remained low as there was not as much rainfall overnight as was forecast. Further rain is forecast for later today so please remain vigilant.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Clyst has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels have risen at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 09/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 2.98m, Bredwardine 4.9m to 5.0m Thursday morning, Belmont 4.8m to 5.0m Thursday afternoon, Old Wye Bridge 4.3m to 4.5m Thursday afternoon, Mordiford 4.1m to 4.4m Thursday evening, Ross-on-wye 3.7m to 4 Friday morning. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 09/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until 10/12/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Leintwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  this evening, 09/12/21 by 17:00, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of Storm Barra Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 09/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.4m to 4.0m Friday morning. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: The level of the River Yeo at Sherborne Lake has now reduced to the Flood Alert level and is stable. Other rivers in the area are back to winter baseflow levels. A band of moderate rain is currently passing over the area, with further sporadic showers expected later this afternoon and evening, Thursday 09/12/2021. While this is not expected to cause widespread flooding impacts, the catchments are wet and it may be enough for Sherborne Lake to rise just above Alert level again, with a low level of flood risk in the local area. Therefore this Alert remains in force as a precautionary measure. We will continue to monitor the weather and the Lake level, and we will keep reviewing the need for this Alert. There may continue to be a localised risk of flooding to low lying land and roads in the area. We do not anticipate flooding of properties, based on the current forecast. Please remain vigilant and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast. This message will be updated by 12:00 tomorrow, Friday 10/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 09/12/21.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  We expect river levels to rise and remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

The risk of flooding from Storm Barra has now reduced.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We have been clearing debris from weed screens and we will continue to monitor the forecast. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' web page for current river levels.

items.description: River Erewash in Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Shipley Gate river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today and tomorrow, 09/12/21 and 10/12/21.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Pinxton, including the Pinxton Wharf access road, Langley Mill, Ilkeston, Stapleford, and the recreation area at Sandiacre.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, 10/12/21. We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated this afternoon, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are high but steady at the Great Bridgford river gauge as a result of rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening and overnight.  Flooding is likely to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   This flood alert remains active as further rainfall is forecast over the next 18 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook

items.message:
River levels are falling at the Pillings Lock river gauge.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast tonight 09/12/2021 and therefore we expect river levels to begin rising again.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  
This message will be updated this evening, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen higher than expected at the Izaac Walton, Ilam and Mayfield river gauges as a result of heavier than expected rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected throughout Thursday.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Dove between Izaak Walton and Rocester and the Henmore Brook between Carsington Dam and Mayfield. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, however, river levels appear to have peaked and are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated this afternoon, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Minor roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood. Peaks:-  Llanymynech 4.21m at 4:15am 09/12; Cae Howel 4.5m to 5.0m overnight tonight.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  this evening, 09/12/21 by 17:00, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high on the River Dee due to heavy rainfall overnight. 
River Levels have gone through the flood alert level this morning, Thursday 9th December 2021.
Flooding is possible of low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. 
Townfield Lane has now been cut off.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. 
This message will be updated in 8 hours, or as the situation changes

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed.  River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted. We continue to monitor the situation.  Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

The combination of ongoing spring tides and strong winds may result in waves overtopping sea defences. The forecast high water is 21:45 on Wednesday, 08/12/21, with a level of 5.33 mAOD and a Force 7 Westerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkely Point. mAOD is height above average sea level. For more detail, please refer to local tide tables. Flooding to low lying coastal roads and farmland is possible this evening, and may occur one to two hours either side of the aforementioned high tide time. Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Strong winds are forecast again for Thursday evening, 09/12/2021, and this flood alert may remain in force for the high tide tomorrow at 22:30. We will keep monitoring the tidal situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, and consider alternative routes. This message will be updated by 16:00 tomorrow, Thursday 09/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.message: We do not expect to see similar impacts for tonight or tomorrow's high tides and no property flooding is expected from this series of high tides. There is no current flood risk from high tides forecast in this area. Although the risk of flooding has now reduced we will continue to monitor levels closely. Please continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom

items.message: Strong winds and moderate waves will continue for much of the week ahead. However, tide levels on Thursday morning are forecast to be lower than that experienced Wednesday morning. None, or minimal, flood impacts are expected. There may still be some minor ponding in Climping Street Car Park but expect this to reduce over the next few days. Including adjustments for the weather, we estimate the water level at 02:45 Thursday morning 9/12/2021 will be 5.27 metres Chart Datum (2.53 mAOD) at Littlehampton. After Thursday morning’s tide, each subsequent morning tide through to Sunday 12/12/2021 will be lower again. We recycled shingle in November and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Our team have been working to return shingle that had been displaced following Storm Barra. We will reissue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: River Wye at Ashford in the Water around Church Street
items.message:
This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation and will re-issue this flood warning if necessary.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: River Bollin and Rossendale Brook at Langley and Sutton
items.message:
This flood warning has been removed. No further flooding is expected in this area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast for today, Thursday 9th December 2021 and re-issue this warning if necessary. 
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

items.description: River Bollin at Macclesfield riverside properties
items.message:
This flood warning has been removed. No further flooding is expected in this area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast for today, Thursday 9th December 2021 and re-issue this warning if necessary. 
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

River levels have risen at the Church Wilne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Church Wilne, Draycott, and Wilne Lane between Draycott and Sawley.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow, 10/12/21.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated this afternoon, 09/12/21, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Warning has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 12 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  

Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Consequently, flooding of property is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Melverley including acre lane. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech peaked and falling, Cae Howel 4.5m to 5.0m overnight tonight, Crew Green 6.1m to 6.3m this afternoon.   
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next few days  We expect river levels to rise until 14:00 on 09/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please move possession and valuables off the ground or to safety and move family, pets and cars to safety.  
This message will be updated  this afternoon, 09/12/21 by 14:00, or as the situation changes.
